Hi Stefano,

Sorry for the slow response. I do feel that ES-HyperNEAT could=
 have some
advantageous compared to the original HyperNEAT when irregularit=
y
increases, although we haven't really investigated this in depth so far.
=
The reasoning here is that it should be easier for ES-HyperNEAT to change
o=
nly a subset of connections and in fact, it often creates networks that
are=
 sparsely connected in contrast to the fully-connected networks often
creat=
ed by HyperNEAT. Also, in the Dual Task domain in our paper:
http://eplex.c=
s.ucf.edu/papers/risi_alife12.pdf, in which the same network
has to learn t=
wo different tasks, it performs significantly better than the
original Hype=
rNEAT because it can only choose to optimize a subset of
weights, which cou=
ld be viewed as some form of irregularity.

In any case, it would be intere=
sting to investigate how ES-HyperNEAT and
Jeff's HybrID compare!

And hopef=
ully that should soon be easier since we are currently working on
a new ES-=
HyperNEAT python implementation that we can hopefully share with
everybody =
sometime in the next few month.

Sebastian

On Mon, Feb 6, 2017 at 9:00 PM,=
 Jeff Clune jclune@... [neat] <
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
> A=
h, I've actually read that paper before but it was a good reread. It
> real=
ly seems as though the fall-off in performance as irregularity
> increases =
for HyperNEAT is dramatic. Would you happen to know if
> ES-HyperNEAT fares=
 better?
>
> I do not. Sebastian Risi or Ken Stanley may.
>
> Note: we have=
 a new paper (resubmitted at the moment, hopefully it will be
> accepted so=
on) coming out on improvements to HybrID that alleviate (but do
> not elimi=
nate) that problem. We=E2=80=99ll post it here (and on the Evolving
> Artif=
icial Intelligence and Complexity Facebook group) once it is ready.
>
> I d=
on't really have any plans for papers soon but I started work on a new
> id=
ea for a genome called a K^2-Graph. Work on the Compositional Adjacency
> M=
atrix Producing Network has stalled for now because I think there could be
=
> some minor bugs with my implementation :s
>
> I'll spare you guys some of=
 what I had written because this conversation
> is veering off-topic and I'=
ve been posting a lot anyway.
>
> If you want to talk about openai environm=
ents, need help, or  want to talk
> about anything really, please email me =
at stefano.r.palmieri@....
>
> Sounds great. Thanks!
>
>
> 
>



-- 
=
Dr. Sebastian Risi
Associate Professor

<div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Stefano,<div><br></div><div>Sorry for the slow response=
. I do feel that ES-HyperNEAT could have some advantageous compared to the =
original HyperNEAT when irregularity increases, although we haven't rea=
lly investigated this in depth so far. The reasoning here is that it should=
 be easier for ES-HyperNEAT to change only a subset of connections and in f=
act, it often creates networks that are sparsely connected in contrast to t=
he fully-connected networks often created by HyperNEAT. Also, in the Dual T=
ask domain in our paper: <a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_ali=
fe12.pdf">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_alife12.pdf</a>, in which the=
 same network has to learn two different tasks, it performs significantly b=
etter than the original HyperNEAT because it can only choose to optimize a =
subset of weights, which could be viewed as some form of irregularity.=C2=
=A0</div><div><br></div><div>In any case, it would be interesting to invest=
igate how ES-HyperNEAT and Jeff's HybrID compare!=C2=A0</div><div><br><=
/div><div>And hopefully that should soon be easier since we are currently w=
orking on a new ES-HyperNEAT python implementation that we can hopefully sh=
are with everybody sometime in the next few month.=C2=A0</div><div><br></di=
